text: The Bent is a weekly management newsletter. I recently recommended their 30-60-90 template to someone who is building from scratch: <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1YqAVDeC2V6G1Z-zVxZFyF01FzyRV4FLBFAw7_cJ3KNY/edit> In my onboarding doc for new hires I also have an intro section that goes over basics like team goals, communication, expectations for things like availability or how to take PTO, etc. It isn’t remote-specific but it’s a good framework for showing people how they’ll ramp and contribute, and setting expectations early.

text: We recently started using Notion and thus far the feedback has been great. We're growing fast and so training is paramount. But it's a lot to take in - so having a library of onboarding resources, organized in specific ways based on feedback from previous hires, is crucial. We also believe in a 30, 60, 90 model and approach our onboarding accordingly. 30 days is training and familiarity with clients, colleagues, concepts, tools and systems. 60 is full-time shadowing on accounts, and by 90 taking on independent projects. This may seem like a long time but I think the investment is crucial to ensure people are equipped to do the job well. Also, i read this quote somewhere that I fully believe and have adopted into our approaches "how you onboard people is the truest measure of how you treat people at your organization."
